utterances: The music you're listening to is by an outfit called The Extra Lens.
It's one of the new songs our colleagues at NPR Music shared on their Song of the Day feature.
Stephen Thompson is the curator of Song of the Day, and he joins me now.
Hello there, Stephen.
Hello, Audie.
So this song is called ""Only Existing Footage."" What can you tell me about this group, The Extra Lens?
Okay, The Extra Lens is led by a guy named John Darnielle, who is better known as the lead singer of The Mountain Goats.

And basically, The Mountain Goats started out at John Darnielle in front of a junky boombox, you know, with fans whirling in the background as he's strumming on an acoustic guitar and singing these kind of bare-knuckle anthems.
Boombox folk.
I haven't heard of this.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Boombox folk, I guess you could say.
And over time, his music has become sort of more polished and beautiful, but the words still hit like a punch in the stomach.
(Soundbite of song, ""Only Existing Footage"")
(Singing) Red-eye back to Belgrade with the footage we can save.
End up with one can because the baggage claim's an unmarked grave.
Hold off the backers, put a notice in the press.
Oblivion's been knocking since I gave it my address.
Again, that's The Extra Lens with ""Only Existing Footage.
Stephen, this next piece comes to us from Brazil, and tell us who this is.
This is a musician named Pedro Moraes, and the song is called ""Zingareio.
(Soundbite of song, ""Zingareio"")
(Singing in foreign language)
That's Pedro Moraes with the song ""Zingareio."" Stephen, what is this song actually about?
Well, a rough translation of ""Zingareio"" is I, gypsy.
Basically, the song is about sort of gypsy identity.
And Pedro Moraes himself is sort of kind of an up-and-comer in Brazil.
He's sort of known for taking the sounds of Brazilian popular music in the '70s and '80s and updating it and twisting it in sort of new styles.
He's known for incorporating the sounds of what he calls electro samba music.
(Soundbite of song, ""Zingareio"")
(Singing in foreign language)
I'm speaking with Stephen Thompson of NPR Music about the tracks featured on Song of the Day.
(Soundbite of song, ""Never Pay for the Farm"")
Stephen, next up, I want to talk about a band called Gang of Four who were trendsetters back in the 1970s.
What song are you going to play for us from them?
Well, this is from an album that comes out in January called ""Content."" The song is called ""Never Pay for the Farm.
(Soundbite of song, ""Never Pay for the Farm"")
(Singing) You'll never pay for the farm, someone should ring the alarm.
I think you're losing the charm.
You cannot do all the harm.
So 30 years later, what's changed about this music?
Well, I mean, this particular song is definitely in the spirit of Gang of Four's early works.
It's interesting because you don't want to sound like a nostalgia act where all you're doing is doing what you did before.
But at the same time, Gang of Four's music, in its original form, still sounds incredibly vital.
And so the fact that this particular track is so reminiscent of its early work, there's still a lot of that spark and a lot of that excitement there.
(Soundbite of song, ""Never Pay for the Farm"")
(Singing) Never pay, never pay for the farm.
They think you're a winner.
Change the locks, change your life.
They think you're a winner.
That's Gang of Four with ""Never Pay for the Farm."" Okay, time for one last track.
This is from an artist named Scuba.
So and what can you tell me about him or them?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, Scuba is an electronic musician named Paul Rose, who owns a fairly influential British electronic label called Hot Flush.
And this particular track is called ""Before (After).
(Soundbite of song, ""Before (After)"")
I guess I shouldn't be surprised that someone named Scuba would make music that sounds like it's underwater.
Yeah.
It's actually one of the challenges, I think, of writing about music like this is not to write sentences like, you know, scuba dives deep into the murky waters of you know, you don't...
Right, the ethereal...
Yeah, you don't want to fall into the trap of that.
But it is a wonderfully fluid sounding mix.

Basically, what this is is a remix of an earlier song that he had done that was just called ""Before."" And in this particular case, it's kind of a woozier and more disorienting version of the song, and it takes you somewhere.
What makes it better than music I would hear when I go to get my nails done at the spa or something, you know, that kind of relax.
I think this for one thing, the sound is much richer and much deeper.
And music like this really, really benefits from very, very good headphones and kind of allowing yourself to become immersed in it, where it's not just a synthesizer going, wah.
The sound has kind of almost three dimensions to it.
And that was the song ""Before (After)"" from the artist Scuba.
General, thanks very much for the phone call.
The step idea for this is record audio clips with photos, then print the photo on the paper.
The stretch idea would be use it in parking garages, so you incorporate it into little ticket and then you can remember where you parked.
And the leap idea is to add audio clips to advertisements in newspapers or magazines.
Four times a year, Kaplan's company, Inventables, delivers a collection of items to clients for display on a special kiosk known as the Innovation Center.
At Radio Flyer, a company that makes wagons and ridable toys, vice president Tom Schlegel says innovation has always been important.
This year, the small family-owned firm won the Academy Award of the toy industry, a TOTY, for its foldable trike.
To sustain creativity and keep the company on top, Radio Flyer subscribes to Inventables.
Each week, we pick a technology from the Inventables' Innovation Center.
We bring it to the whole group and we research it and talk about it, and then see how can we apply it to our products.
Subscribers pay up to $250,000 a year, and for some, the investment really pays off.
Take Griffin Technologies, a small firm that developed and sold tens of thousands of iTrips, FM transmitters that allow people to play tunes from their iPod Nano in the car.
The challenge was how to attach the iPod to the iTrip without detracting from its sleek design.
Inventables had just the thing.
You're familiar with suction cups, right?
Well, this was a tape just like normal tape, except for the fact that instead of being sticky, it had micro-suction cups on there.
There are at least a dozen companies like Inventables founded to help firms innovate.

Henry Chesbrough, executive director of the Center for Open Innovation at UC Berkeley, says these consultants are beginning to replace the traditional corporate model for research and development, a model that required companies to develop their own materials and technologies.
